3:52 this does actually have some truth to it, the weakest part of the grip is the thumb. If someone grabs your wrist, twist it quickly towards their thumb and they can almost never hold on. As someone who has fired some guns in the past, it's actually pretty difficult to hit an exact spot in distance even when you are calm. If the target is very close to you let's say around 7-8m you will most likely be able to hit very close to it or if you are experienced even 100% on point. But if you are at let's say 20m-30m it's practically ver  very difficult to hit the target with a pistol since (based on physics) a very very very minor movement of the pistol (ex breathing) causes a considerable negative from the target. Even worse when you are under stress (ex police during the duty etc etc.) But that's a whole other story. Love your videos Pewds and Ken

“The hand is not meant to hold things very well.”        






That’s the one thing they were made to do

This blue stick is actually called Kubotan.
The origin of kubotan is quite fresh, it was created in the 20th century by the master of martial arts, Sōke Takayuki Kubota.
Even tha it looks funny its pretty usuful self defence tool. 
Common uses include hardening the fist (fistload) for punching, attacking vulnerable parts of an assailant's body, and gaining leverage on an assailant's wrist, fingers and joints. 
With keys attached, it can function as a flailing weapon. As a pressure point weapon it can attack any point a finger can, but with greater penetration because of the smaller surface area at the ends. 
For example, a law enforcement officer may wrap his arm around a suspect's neck while simultaneously digging the end of the Kubotan into the small of his back.

Most of the stuff this guy shows is technically ‘true’ but completely irrational to even think about trying.

Small side note: the requirements for owning an assault rifle in many states are legal ones (i.e. having a clean record) and are not based on experience. So, owning an assault rifle does not mean that the person knows how to use it. Especially with ammo prices right now, gun owners don't have the money to practice.

The second clip is what you learn in Jiujitsu tho. Since the thumbs are supposed to be the weakest when someone grabs you like that. A quick strong pull towards the thumbs of the agressor will get you lose 8/10 times. I got away from a robbery like that when I was a late teen. I have done Jiujitsu for a couple of years prior to that mugging.
